text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

IRM 11.3.23.1 - Revised the title to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Background - Added background information on Disclosures to the Government Accountability Office (GAO). Information from the prior section
, Authority for Disclosure, was incorporated into this section. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities governing Disclosures to the Government Accountability Office (GAO). c. IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities - This IRM applies to all IRS personnel providing records under the provisions of IRM
d. IRM
, Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and abbreviations and their deﬁnitions regarding Disclosures to the Government Accountability (GAO). e. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the Government Accountability Office audit and disclosure processes.
Deleted IRM section 11.3.23.9 which was identiﬁed as a reserved section. No content needed for that section so it has been removed. All subsequent subsections were renumbered accordingly.
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
The Disclosure and Privacy Virtual Library is at: https://portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vl003/pages/default.aspx

) Purpose: This IRM section provides instructions concerning the disclosure of returns and return information to the Government Accountability Office and pursuant to IRC §

) Audience: these procedures apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the Ser- vicewide Disclosure policy. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The office of Audit Coordination has responsibility for disclosures to the Government Accountability Office (GAO). (

In audits of other federal agencies, GAO also may have access, pursuant to a written request to the IRS, to information that has not been obtained by a federal agency, but which is able to be disclosed to such agency under IRC §6103(l) or IRC §6103(m) for agency programs or activities are the subject of GAO’s audit.

GAO may have access to returns and return information pursuant to IRC §6103(p)(6) in the performance of safeguard reviews. In this situation GAO must notify the Secretary of Treasury before any such audit is conducted.
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
) Generally, the reviews described in (
), and (

) above are considered to be tax reviews of the IRS involving those aspects of the IRS’s activities with the administration of the internal revenue laws. a. These reviews may require disclosure of returns and return information GAO officers and employees and/or inspection of returns and return mation by GAO officers and employees. b. As part of these tax reviews, GAO may also have access to information that does not constitute returns and return information. (

) GAO also conducts non-tax reviews of the IRS. a. These reviews can entail audits of the IRS’s non-tax activities such as curement, payroll, settlement of accountable officers’ accounts and/or review of IRS’s accounting systems. b. Since these reviews are not a review of the IRS’s tax activities in tion with the administration of the internal revenue laws, the GAO will normally require disclosure of returns and return information. c. As part of these non-tax reviews, the GAO may have access to non-tax information. (
) No disclosure of tax or non-tax information in a tax or non-tax review will be made unless it is veriﬁed that the request is part of an authorized review of IRS. (

Information, the disclosure of which is governed solely by the Privacy Act, 5 USC §552a, may be released to GAO as part of either a tax or non-tax review. Under 5 USC §552a(b)(10), GAO is exempted from the requirement that the individual to whom the information pertains must consent to release.
The Director for the Office of Audit Coordination is the IRS’s designated central contact point on GAO matters and is also responsible for authorization issues.

) Additional Information may also be found at: • Privacy and Disclosure Virtual Library Article - Disclosures to General Accountability Office (GAO). (
) The IRS will give GAO the broadest possible cooperation within the limits of the law, and will make every effort to promptly furnish the information requested by GAO. (
) Oral requests for information will be complied with as long as they fall within the scope of an authorized review. A record documenting the request should be prepared. (
) Original records may not be taken from an IRS office, even if the GAO office in the same building. GAO may be provided with copies of any documents they are authorized to examine. (
) Within the scope of their authorization, GAO employees may interview IRS personnel.

) Problems regarding the scope of a review are to be resolved by the Office Audit Coordination. (
) GAO advises the IRS in writing when it is expanding a review to include functions. (
) The Office of Audit Coordination issues a memorandum to the affected functions at Headquarters advising of the expansion. (
) In urgent situations, the Office of Audit Coordination will telephone the func- tional GAO liaison once the authorization has been signed. (

and the secrecy clause of the treaty, and may disclosed to GAO only in accordance with IRC §
or the secrecy whichever provides the greater protection. (

) Information received from a foreign government pursuant to a tax treaty subject to treaty secrecy clauses may be disclosed to GAO when it acts agent of one of the Congressional tax-writing committees. (

Any information that is available to GAO during a non-tax review, or is available to the general public, is available to GAO during a tax review. Information received from a foreign government pursuant to a tax treaty and subject to treaty secrecy clauses may be disclosed to GAO when it acts as agent of one of the Congressional tax-writing committees. If any questions arise regarding the scope of GAO reviews or the need to make impairment calls, they will be raised through channels to PGLD or the Office of Audit Coordination, as appropriate.

) Information that may be disclosed to GAO during a non-tax review includes, but is not limited to, the following: to a. Portions of the IRM available to the public with b. IRS Manuals and ADP Handbooks Note: See IRM

, for speciﬁc instructions. c. Records such as official personnel ﬁles, time cards, travel vouchers, other ﬁscal documents d. ) GAO may examine IRS manuals and similar material in the ADP Handbook, which is Document

, IRS Processing Codes and Information. This includes background and historical records, when reviewing IRS operations part of a tax or non-tax review. a. They may also examine documents that contain sensitive law procedures or ADP material. b. This is not intended to include the disclosure of return information or taxpayer identities that are to be protected under IRC §
during a tax review. (

) In view of the sensitive nature of this material, GAO has agreed to the following procedures for obtaining access to it. a. The GAO audit manager or site supervisor will advise the appropriate manager (e.g., functional GAO Liaison) of the name of the GAO authorized to obtain, and if necessary, copy the sensitive law Official Use Only or Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed ADP material, as well as documents that contain sensitive law enforcement procedures or ADP material. This individual will be responsible for security of the material. b. The IRS manager also should maintain a record showing what material were inspected and/or copied by GAO and the date. The documents are not to leave the IRS office. c. GAO auditors visiting IRS offices are required to maintain security over sensitive information and documents consistent with the level of required by the documents. Work papers containing sensitive IRS are retained separately by GAO in locked red-seal storage for a of three years before they are shredded under supervised conditions. (
) GAO requests for Chief Counsel documents addressed to IRS officials and located in IRS ﬁles will be treated the same as requests for other IRS documents. (
) Any questions regarding the disclosure of such documents will be directed PGLD, who will coordinate with the Associate Chief Counsel, Procedure and Administration.
c. Records such as official personnel ﬁles, time cards, travel vouchers, and other ﬁscal documents d. Narrative reports of IRS activities, which do not constitute return informa

tion, provided any return information contained therein is deleted; and e. Documents marked “FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY,” or “SENSITIVE BUT UNCLASSIFIED”, unless they contain returns or return information, in which case that information must be redacted.

a. The GAO audit manager or site supervisor will advise the appropriate IRS manager (e.g., functional GAO Liaison) of the name of the GAO auditor(s) authorized to obtain, and if necessary, copy the sensitive law enforcement, Official Use Only or Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed ADP material, as well as documents that contain sensitive law enforcement procedures or ADP material. This individual will be responsible for security of the material. b. The IRS manager also should maintain a record showing what documents/ material were inspected and/or copied by GAO and the date. The original documents are not to leave the IRS office. c. GAO auditors visiting IRS offices are required to maintain security over sensitive information and documents consistent with the level of security required by the documents. Work papers containing sensitive IRS matters are retained separately by GAO in locked red
seal storage for a maximum of three years before they are shredded under supervised conditions.
GAO requests for Chief Counsel documents addressed to IRS officials and located in IRS ﬁles will be treated the same as requests for other IRS documents.
Any questions regarding the disclosure of such documents will be directed to PGLD, who will coordinate with the Associate Chief Counsel, Procedure and

) GAO requests for Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration will be directed to TIGTA. TIGTA (
) TIGTA has agreed to provide any reports directly to GAO if they are in connection with an ongoing tax review. (
) GAO has agreed that it will contact taxpayers only if authorized to do so by congressional committee on whose behalf it is acting, or in the matter of Taxpayers IRC §

) audit, by the Joint Committee on Taxation. a. GAO will provide the appropriate functional GAO coordinator with a list taxpayers to contact so that the function can coordinate a search for open cases. b. Any taxpayer for whom there is an open case will not be contacted the approval of the appropriate functional Senior Manager. (
) The Senior Manager will contact the affected division if approval for contact cannot be resolved. (

(a)) must be accounted for pursuant to the Privacy Act, in accordance with, the instructions contained IRM
, Privacy Act Accounting for Disclosures. (

) The component of the business unit that discloses the records to GAO is sponsible for completion of the disclosure accounting. a. Accounting forms are accessible on the IRS intranet website at: Publishing Website. Note: See IRM
) and (
) for disclosures made through the Office of dit Coordination to GAO. (

-B, Multiple Record of Disclosure, may be prepared by GAO personnel. a. The original copy should be furnished to the IRS and a copy by GAO for its recordkeeping system as required by IRC §
). b. The completed forms should be reviewed on a sample basis for and completeness. Note: See IRM
